Approach and Execution: Query Komodo for newly credentialed rheumatologists or recent relocations (NPI changes and new billing addresses) within last 12-18 months. Cross-reference against current call universe to identify gaps.
Value: High - First impressions shape years of prescribing behavior. Low-cost patient acquisition with long LTV.
Action Approach to Realize Value: Generate target list quarterly. Brief field force on prioritization. Arm reps with clinical onboarding kits. Track new Rx starts from these HCPs as KPI.
Risk: Low - Straightforward data pull with clear field application. No controversial messaging required.
Difficulty and Why: Low - Standard NPI and claims-based filtering. No complex modeling required.
Time/Effort Involved: 2-3 weeks to initial target list; quarterly refresh

Approach and Execution: Aggregate IBD diagnosis codes (Crohns and UC) at practice level. Score practices by IBD prevalence in patient panel. Filter for rheumatology practices with bottom-quartile IBD comorbidity.
Value: High - Removes the primary IL-17 objection before it arises. Reps lead with efficacy not defense.
Action Approach to Realize Value: Segment call list into IBD-clean vs IBD-prevalent. Tailor messaging tracks. Measure conversion rate differential between segments.
Risk: Low - Uses standard diagnosis code aggregation. Clear clinical rationale.
Difficulty and Why: Low - Simple prevalence calculation at practice level. No predictive modeling.
Time/Effort Involved: 2-3 weeks; static segmentation with annual refresh

Approach and Execution: Query biologic prescribing (NDC and J-codes) by specialty. Identify dermatologists and physiatrists and PCPs writing biologics for inflammatory arthritis indications. Rank by volume.
Value: High - Untapped call universe with less entrenched brand loyalty. Often overlooked by rheum-focused teams.
Action Approach to Realize Value: Create separate target list for non-rheum prescribers. Consider dedicated specialty overlay or adjusted call routing. Track share gains in this segment.
Risk: Medium - May require cross-functional alignment if derm team exists. Messaging needs specialty-appropriate tailoring.
Difficulty and Why: Low to Medium - Straightforward prescribing query but requires specialty code filtering and indication inference.

Approach and Execution: Filter Komodo for mid-level providers (NPs and PAs) with biologic prescribing authority in rheumatology or derm settings. Identify those actively writing biologics vs those with potential.
Value: High - Under-called segment with growing prescribing authority. Less brand entrenchment than MDs.
Action Approach to Realize Value: Add qualified mid-levels to call universe. Develop tailored educational materials. Track Rx lift from this segment separately.
Risk: Low - Clear data criteria. Growing acceptance of mid-level targeting in pharma.
Difficulty and Why: Low - Standard provider filtering by credential type and prescribing activity.

Approach and Execution: Identify practices with recent uptick in TNF biosimilar prescribing (Hadlima and Hyrimoz etc) indicating active therapy management. Flag as high-priority for mechanism-of-action switch conversations.
Value: High - Catches physicians in active treatment decision mode. Natural opening for new mechanism discussion.
Action Approach to Realize Value: Time rep visits to biosimilar transition windows. Arm reps with MOA differentiation messaging. Track competitive switches from biosimilar-active practices.
Risk: Low to Medium - Requires timely data refresh to catch transition windows.
Difficulty and Why: Medium - Needs rolling biosimilar volume monitoring at practice level.
Time/Effort Involved: 4-5 weeks initial build; monthly refresh recommended

Approach and Execution: Flag practices with elevated JAK inhibitor discontinuation rates or switches away from JAKs. These physicians may have safety concerns making them receptive to IL-17 alternative.
Value: High - Clear safety narrative reps can deliver. Timely given ongoing JAK regulatory scrutiny.
Action Approach to Realize Value: Prioritize JAK-discontinuing practices in call routing. Equip reps with comparative safety messaging. Track conversion rates.
Risk: Low - Leverages real prescribing behavior. Safety messaging is on-label.
Difficulty and Why: Medium - Requires discontinuation inference from Rx gaps or therapy switches.

Approach and Execution: Identify derm practices with high psoriasis volume plus elevated musculoskeletal codes (joint pain and enthesopathy) or NSAID prescribing patterns suggesting undiagnosed PsA.
Value: Very High - Market creation opportunity. These patients need a biologic covering both skin and joints.
Action Approach to Realize Value: Target high-signal derm practices with disease education. Partner with medical affairs for PsA awareness initiatives. Track biologic initiation from flagged practices.
Risk: Medium - Requires inference from indirect signals. Messaging is educational not promotional.
Difficulty and Why: Medium - Multi-code pattern matching at practice level. Not complex but requires clinical logic validation.

Approach and Execution: Track practice-level surges in imaging orders (MRI and ultrasound) and steroid injections and rheumatology referrals indicating active disease management moments. Time rep engagement accordingly.
Value: High - Optimizes when to show up not just where. Catches practices during peak decision-making.
Action Approach to Realize Value: Generate monthly practice-level activity scores. Route reps to high-activity practices. Test conversion lift vs static targeting.
Risk: Low to Medium - Requires ongoing data refresh and field coordination on timing.
Difficulty and Why: Medium - Rolling aggregation and anomaly detection at practice level.

Approach and Execution: Identify practices with patterns suggesting undiagnosed axSpA: chronic low back pain in younger adults plus repeated NSAIDs plus sacroiliac imaging but no rheumatology follow-through.
Value: Very High - Market creation in underdiagnosed population. Bimzelx has strong axSpA data.
Action Approach to Realize Value: Target high-signal practices with disease education. Partner with medical affairs on axSpA awareness. Track referral and diagnosis rates from flagged practices.
Risk: Medium - Requires physician education on diagnostic criteria. Longer sales cycle.
Difficulty and Why: Medium to High - Complex multi-signal pattern matching. Needs clinical validation of logic.

Approach and Execution: Identify practices with high infusion biologic volume (Remicade and Inflectra and infliximab biosimilars). These may be receptive to SQ convenience especially if capacity-constrained.
Value: Medium to High - Clear value proposition around convenience and capacity. Differentiated positioning.
Action Approach to Realize Value: Segment infusion-heavy practices. Develop messaging around administration convenience and site-of-care flexibility. Track SQ conversion rates.
Risk: Medium - Infusion revenue may create inertia. Requires understanding practice economics.
Difficulty and Why: Low to Medium - Straightforward J-code volume aggregation by practice.

Approach and Execution: Calculate biologic persistence rates (across all brands) by practice. High-persistence practices likely have strong patient selection or support infrastructure.
Value: Medium to High - New starts at high-persistence practices more likely to stick. Better LTV per patient.
Action Approach to Realize Value: Prioritize high-persistence practices in targeting. Understand what drives their success. Replicate support models where possible.
Risk: Low - Retrospective analysis with clear logic.
Difficulty and Why: Medium - Requires patient-level persistence calculation then practice-level aggregation.

Approach and Execution: Identify practices managing both psoriasis and PsA populations. These benefit from unified Bimzelx messaging across indications.
Value: Medium - Efficiency play for field force. Consistent messaging reinforcement.
Action Approach to Realize Value: Flag multi-indication practices for coordinated derm-rheum messaging. Align rep teams if separate. Track cross-indication prescribing.
Risk: Low - Standard indication and specialty analysis.
Difficulty and Why: Low - Diagnosis code filtering by practice.

Approach and Execution: Identify rheumatology practices with elevated cardiometabolic comorbidity (diabetes and CVD and metabolic syndrome) in patient panels. IL-17 CV safety profile may resonate.
Value: Medium - Differentiated safety messaging for relevant patient population.
Action Approach to Realize Value: Segment practices by comorbidity burden. Develop CV safety messaging track. Measure adoption in high-comorbidity segment.
Risk: Medium - CV safety messaging requires careful compliance review. Must stay on-label.
Difficulty and Why: Low to Medium - Comorbidity code aggregation at practice level.

Approach and Execution: Classify practices as academic medical centers vs community rheumatology. Tailor messaging depth and style accordingly.
Value: Medium - Academics may want data depth while community wants real-world simplicity and efficiency.
Action Approach to Realize Value: Segment call lists by practice type. Develop differentiated messaging tracks and leave-behinds. Test conversion by segment.
Risk: Low - Standard segmentation approach.
Difficulty and Why: Low - Practice classification using existing taxonomies.

Approach and Execution: Infer practice capacity constraints from referral-to-first-visit lag times in claims. Congested practices may prefer therapies that simplify monitoring.
Value: Medium - Indirect signal but could inform messaging around ease of use and monitoring burden.
Action Approach to Realize Value: Flag capacity-constrained practices. Test messaging around simplified management. Monitor adoption lift.
Risk: Medium - Difficult to message directly. Inference is indirect.
Difficulty and Why: Medium to High - Requires visit sequencing analysis and lag time calculation.

Approach and Execution: Score practices by average time patients remain on conventional DMARDs despite disease progression signals. High inertia practices are undertreating eligible patients.
Value: Medium to High - Identifies undertreated populations. But changing ingrained behavior is difficult.
Action Approach to Realize Value: Flag high-inertia practices for intensified education. Partner with medical affairs on treat-to-target messaging. Long-term tracking required.
Risk: Medium to High - Deeply ingrained prescriber behavior. Long sales cycle to change.
Difficulty and Why: High - Requires disease progression inference and treatment duration analysis.

Approach and Execution: Map claims-based PsA and axSpA prevalence estimates against biologic utilization by geography. Where burden is high but penetration low something structural is suppressing treatment.
Value: Medium to High - Strategic insight for territory planning and resource allocation.
Action Approach to Realize Value: Use for territory alignment and resource deployment decisions. Investigate root causes in gap regions. May inform market access or medical affairs priorities.
Risk: Low - Analytic insight not field messaging.
Difficulty and Why: Medium - Prevalence estimation and geographic aggregation.

Approach and Execution: Map PA rejection rates and time-to-approval by payer and geography. Identifies where administrative friction suppresses treatment.
Value: Medium - Valuable intelligence but not field-actionable.
Action Approach to Realize Value: Share with market access team for payer negotiation priorities. May inform hub services resource deployment.
Risk: Low - Analytic insight.
Difficulty and Why: Medium - Requires PA outcome tracking which may need supplementary data.

Approach and Execution: Identify which specialty pharmacies dominate in high-value territories. Understand distribution network dynamics.
Value: Low to Medium - Informs partnership or pull-through strategy but not rep-actionable.
Action Approach to Realize Value: Share with trade and distribution team. May inform SP partnership priorities or patient support routing.
Risk: Low - Structural analysis.
Difficulty and Why: Low to Medium - SP claims aggregation by geography.

Approach and Execution: Map geographies with low rheumatologist density but high disease burden. Identifies access gaps requiring non-field solutions.
Value: Medium - Market development opportunity but requires infrastructure investment not field effort.
Action Approach to Realize Value: Share with market development and patient services teams. May inform telemedicine partnerships or hub expansion.
Risk: Low - Strategic planning input.
Difficulty and Why: Low to Medium - Provider density mapping against prevalence estimates.
